race.name: Garmin Gravel Worlds
race.tagline: Nebraska rolling farmland gravel in Lincoln.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and wind possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling Nebraska farmland. Moderate elevation with farmland scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional NE event. Rolling farmland terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Garmin Gravel Worlds is a regional event in Lincoln, Nebraska (not to be confused with UCI Gravel Worlds). The rolling farmland terrain offers moderate climbing with farmland scenery, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Lincoln provides good access. It's a solid regional event for Nebraska cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Nebraska gravel race with rolling farmland terrain. Worth it for Nebraska cyclists seeking a local event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Nebraska rolling farmland gravel in Lincoln.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Nebraska and want a local rolling farmland event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better events: Gravel Worlds (UCI), Unbound. For similar regional events: other NE gravel races.

logistics.food: Lincoln has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Rolling Nebraska farmland gravel with moderate climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Nebraska rolling farmland gravel in Lincoln.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: 2024 75 Garmin Gravel Worlds p/b Goodlife Cyclery

non_negotiables.why: Nebraska rolling farmland requires sustained effort.
NE summer/fall means heat and wind are likely.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Nebraska rolling farmland gravel in Lincoln.

logistics.explanation: The fairgrounds venue provides "a massive structure to house all of the vendors. And plenty of parking," according to finisher Mathew Wollmann. The Graduate by Hilton Hotels in Lincoln offers nearby accommodation, with downtown options like Napoli's Haymarket for pre-race carb loading. Staggered start times from 5:55am prevent chaos, though course marking requires GPS backup as signs "may be altered or stolen."

length.explanation: Multiple distance options let riders choose their suffering level - 35 miles with 2,000 feet, 75 miles with 5,000 feet, or the full 150 miles with 10,000+ feet of climbing. Wollmann completed the 300-mile ultra in 21:53, hanging with the front group until mile 12 before "pretty much solo work with a passer-by to chat with the entire night." The 150-mile had a 35% DNF rate in 2024's heat.

technicality.explanation: "The gravel roads were halfway decent, with only a few with big chunky rocks," reports koalb. Dbecker27 confirms "the gravel is not chunky at all and smooth," though warns of "sections of soft gravel which can through you off line" on descents. The technical challenge comes from managing speed over endless rollers rather than handling skills through rock gardens or technical features.

elevation.explanation: "It's very up and down and not flat, despite the perception of nebraska being pancake flat," explains hubcyclist. The course features "a lot of punchy little climbs which you then coast down" according to Dbecker27. koalb describes riding "the gravel seas" with constant ups and downs where "none of the climbs are that big, but there are a ton of them."

climate.explanation: 2024 delivered brutal heat with temperatures hitting 100°F and heat indexes of 105°F. KCBikeNerd reported "mile 60-120 right into a furnace headwind" that "slaughtered the mid/tail end of the 'party pace' folks." Wollmann began "to stop sweating, developed a headache, and the cramps got worse" before needing an IV at the finish. The heat forecast caused 250-300 original registrants to drop to shorter distances.

altitude.explanation: Nebraska farmland sits near sea level with no altitude impact on performance or training adaptation. The rolling hills create elevation gain through repetition, not actual altitude that affects oxygen availability or requires acclimatization.

adventure.explanation: The 300-mile ultra starts at 5pm Friday for an all-night adventure through Nebraska's "rolling gravel seas." Wollmann describes "yelling out loud to wake up" during the dark hours and hiking his bike around a train blocking the road at mile 250. The self-supported format means gas station stops and strategic naps, though the terrain itself offers agricultural grinding rather than wilderness exploration.

prestige.explanation: World championship jerseys for the 150-mile winners and 16 years of history give Gravel Worlds regional credibility. The Vegan Cyclist's appearance and "a lot of familiar faces and names in the ultra community" suggest growing recognition. However, the field depth remains modest with ~150 starters in the flagship distance, indicating it hasn't reached the status of gravel's premier events.

race_quality.explanation: Aid stations are "VERY well stocked" with "almost anything you could ask for" including free hot dogs and brats offered by locals. The fairgrounds venue upgrade shows organizational improvement. However, course marking reliability issues requiring GPS backup and the multi-sport weekend format spreading focus across various disciplines prevent this from reaching elite race standards.

experience.explanation: The multi-day festival atmosphere at the fairgrounds creates a proper gravel celebration. Wollmann describes the pre-race ritual of pasta at Napoli's Haymarket and drinks at Starlite Lounge. The "First To Last" philosophy ensures every finisher gets celebrated equally, with medical tents providing free IVs for heat casualties. Three distance options accommodate different ambitions within the same weekend event structure.

community.explanation: "Gravel worlds is one of the races that's dedicated to preserving the founding principle of gravel that we celebrate first place to last place equally," explains coordinator Hannah Shell. Wollmann notes the "outpouring of support from everyone" visible through phone notifications during the race. The event maintains gravel's original "adventure, not so much a competition" ethos while building a 16-year community around shared suffering.

field_depth.explanation: The 150-mile distance attracted approximately 150 starters in 2024, with only 97 finishing due to extreme heat. Elite categories exist with dedicated start times, but no notable pro winners are documented. The ultra-distance events draw "familiar faces and names in the ultra community" according to Wollmann, suggesting a specialized rather than broadly competitive field.

value.explanation: Multiple distance options and the multi-day festival format provide flexibility for different rider goals and budgets. Trophy payouts extend to all categories rather than just elite placings. The well-stocked aid stations, free medical support, and "VERY well stocked aid station" at mile 270 of the ultra course demonstrate substantial included support services, though specific registration fees weren't available for comparison.

expenses.explanation: Lincoln's cost of living keeps accommodation reasonable, with Wollmann staying at the Graduate by Hilton Hotels. The centralized fairgrounds venue eliminates shuttle costs and provides ample parking. Pre-race dining options like Napoli's Haymarket offer standard pricing, and the Nebraska location generally provides manageable travel and lodging expenses compared to destination resort race locations.
